qas.question: Asthma that is the result of or made worse by workplace exposure is reported as what?
What percent of asthma cases in adults are work-related?
What are some of the most common agents?

answers.text: isocyanates, grain and wood dust, colophony, soldering flux, latex, animals, and aldehydes

qas.question: What professions normally have the highest risk of problems?

answers.text: those who spray paint, bakers and those who process food, nurses, chemical workers, those who work with animals, welders, hairdressers and timber workers

qas.question: What is colophony commonly reported as when caused or made worse by workplace exposure?
What happens to many cases of colophony?
How many adult colophony cases are work-related?
Name a few professions that have the highest risk of colophony?
What are two agents that are commonly believed to cause colophony?

context: Asthma as a result of (or worsened by) workplace exposures, is a commonly reported <a0_0><b4_0>occupational disease<b4_0/><a0_0/>. Many cases however <b5_0>are not reported<b5_0/> or recognized as such. <a1_0>It is estimated that <b6_0>5–25%<b6_0/><a1_0/> of asthma cases in adults are work–related. A few hundred different agents have been implicated with the most common being: <a2_0>isocyanates, grain and wood dust, colophony, soldering flux, latex, <b8_0>animals, and aldehydes<b8_0/><a2_0/>. The employment associated with the highest risk of problems include: <a3_0>those who spray paint, bakers and those who process food, nurses, chemical workers, those who work with animals, <b7_0>welders, hairdressers and timber workers<b7_0/><a3_0/>.
